text: been reading through some of the resources on this site and thinking about how we can integrate them into our discussions. there’s some pretty interesting stuff here: <http://toolsforchange.org/resources/>

```Consumerism is more than greed. It is
the frenzied effort to belong. Our
identity has become what we own. The
richness of our various cultural
heritages has been replaced by a
“white” identity whose roots are not in
a history of a people with a particular
place, culture and language. “White”
identity was born out of the
establishment and maintenance of
privilege. ```

<!channel>: implicit bias test: <https://implicit.harvard.edu/implicit/takeatest.html>

and reposting for those new to the channel, super interesting podcast with the woman who created the test: <http://www.onbeing.org/program/mahzarin-banaji-the-mind-is-a-difference-seeking-machine/8719>

attachments.title: Mahzarin Banaji — The Mind Is a Difference-Seeking Machine
attachments.text: Social psychologist Mahzarin Banaji sees the mind as a "difference-seeking machine" that helps us order reality, and that creates biases. This science takes our grappling with difference out of the realm of guilt, into the realm of transformative good.
attachments.fallback: On Being: Mahzarin Banaji — The Mind Is a Difference-Seeking Machine

<!here|@here>: if you are interested and I highly recommend - link to unconscious bias training on august 8th - <https://impactflow.com/event/techtown-portland-baseline-training-272>

attachments.title: TechTown Portland Baseline Training, Portland
attachments.text: Baseline Training SessionsOpen to All Employees of TechTown Diversity Pledge Companies3-4 hour sessions with multiple dates & times; see individual sessions for details; please select one session only.Conversations with the companies that have signed the TechTown Diversity Pledge have revealed a wide range of experiences and comfort on the topic of diversity in tech. In conversations with company executives we agreed that providing baseline training for employees of all diversity pledge companies would be a valuable resource.The desire to bring more diverse talent to the tech industry must be coupled with awareness efforts in order to more fully realize the benefits of an increasingly diverse workforce. The Baseline Training Sessions will establish a baseline level of awareness of the complexity of diversity and inclusion. The trainings will be particularly valuable for employees new to this topic, although they’re designed to provide value regardless of employee position within the organization, experience level with diversity, or identity as part of an underrepresented or dominant population.MONDAY, AUGUST 8, 2016 - 1:00 - 5:00 p.m.PDC, 222 NW Fifth Ave., First FloorThis interactive session led by Figure 8 Consulting helps identify barriers to inclusion and outstanding customer service, finding answers through an exploration of cultural agility and the development of true allyship. We partner with organizations to create unique solutions to the challenges they face. Our work is grounded in the belief that relationships are the foundation for cultural agility, and that cultural humility leads us to communicate better and to find ways to accommodate and find strength in our differences.
attachments.fallback: ImpactFlow: TechTown Portland Baseline Training, Portland

text: that girl wanted sign is pretty lame
it hangs in the conference room that men use 99% of the time… outside the ecd area
this idea "Kill Subjectivity with Specificity” is so on point. i’ve been thinking a lot about it since the unconscious bias training (thats happening again in august and mentioned ^^^)
i love the idea of reviewing resumes and portfolios blindly
<@U167FL70V> - i agree

yea it was crazy. we had meetings of women in the agency and even the female recruiters were jaded and tired of bringing books to the cds and ecds of types of people that they knew they would reject on the spot
all of our jaws dropped when they said that
and they can say “the work comes first” but the focus wasn’t on creating a diverse breadth of work that solved problems from many perspectives
jeez
OOOHHHH boy do I have a story to share on this.
it’s so true that typically people like the style/type of work that they themselves do
^YES
i think in some ways it makes more sense to hire someone who is outside of the target group of the work, to keep asking all the right questions about the end usability and necessity of the thing
yea! keep poking the bear!
Ok, so I have a similar story to share from a big Motion Design conference I attended last fall up in Vancouver, BC
<@U0J6TE0CA|emilyskaer> uploaded a file: <https://uncorked.slack.com/files/emilyskaer/F1RGQBR7Y/hmmmm.jpg|Hmmmm>
They had a bunch of panels, only two of which contained women. Only one was an animator.
During the panel of the picture above, I asked “What are you doing internally to ensure the message you are crafting comes from a diverse set of creatives?"
All the men kind of fell silent. Honey, from Buck agency, got all cocky & just said “We pull in talent from all around the world"
They all continued down this path, patting themselves on the back.

I clarified, “What are you doing to ensure you have diversity in gender and race to craft a more well rounded message to your diverse audiences?”. I knew if I catered the question on money being the target, they’d respond. Instead, they just pat themselves on the back more.
Their agencies are mostly while straight males, not just the top dogs.
After the session broke, I had people from different gender and racial backgrounds coming up to me & thanking me for the question.
While incredibly uncomfortable, it started a HUGE dialog in the community & brought up the issue.

i have a facebook friend/former colleague who is a CEO (Mattermark) and I think it was her that complained the other side of that issue… that as a female succeeding in a male dominated field, she’s a checkbox invite to panels and conferences. im probably getting her complaint wrong but the gist was “because there is imbalance it punishes those who are helping the counterbalance"
tokenism is a real thing
I love incredibly uncomfortable questions. Nice work <@U0J6TE0CA>
<@U0J6TE0CA>: that is so awesome
I kind of got disregarded until a TOTAL badass in the business, Lilian Darmono, backed me. <http://www.liliandarmono.com/>

per blind resumes - before i was at uncorked, i applied at Treehouse, and they have a pretty robust blind vetting process - resumes submitted blind, initial tech test and responses to first round questions are blind - only then do hiring managers get to know who they’ll be interviewing
not sure if we have any contacts there to poke on their process
<@U06DFL7BP>: My friend Leanne works there & I’m having dinner with her tomorrow
BOOM
DONE
:thumbsup: i was very impressed with their practices!
